knowledge.title: Diagnosing Diabetes
knowledge.description: This system assesses the risk of people having diabetes and also presents the user with lifestyle improvements to lower the risk of diabetes and to help people to live a healthier life.

goal.name: RiskDiabetesType2
goal.answer: You have a low risk of diabetes type 2.

You have a medium risk of diabetes type 2. We advice you to visit a doctor to take a diabetes test. A simple blood test at your general practitioner can quickly confirm this. It will be especially valuable to also follow the lifestyle given below. A good and healthy lifestyle can help to decrease the risk of forming diabetes type 2 and can also significantly improve your life if you suffer from diabetes.

You have a high risk of diabetes type 2. YWe advice you to visit a doctor to take a diabetes test. A simple blood test at your general practitioner can quickly confirm this. It will be especially valuable to follow the lifestyle tips given below. A good and healthy lifestyle can help to decrease the risk of forming diabetes type 2 and can also improve your life if you suffer from diabetes.

goal.name: RiskDiabetesType1
goal.answer: You have a medium risk of diabetes type 1. We advice you to visit a doctor to take a diabetes test. A simple blood test at your general practitioner can quickly confirm this.
You have a high risk of diabetes type 1. We advice you to visit a doctor and take a diabetes test. A simple blood test at your general practitioner can quickly confirm this.

You are experiencing the symptoms of a ketoacidose, this an advanced and dangerous stage of diabetes type 1. We advice you to go to call a doctor as soon as possible or possibly call the emergency services.

Your symptoms seem to be unrelated to diabetes type 1, but could be caused by another diseases such as diabetes type 2 (see the above test result for your risk on diabetes type 2), or something else, we do advice you to see a doctor.

goal.name: AdviceSport
goal.answer: We advice you to increase the amount of exercise you do significantly. Exercise reduces the risk of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, depressive complaints, breast cancer, colon cancer, mental decline and dementia. Ideally, you should exercise actively for at least 2.5 hours a week (for example walking, cycling, running, playing football, fitness, dancing, martial arts). Also do activities that strengthen muscles and bones, such as exercise or strength training. And avoid sitting still a lot. Choose exercise / sports activities that suit you, but do not set your goals too high at the start. Even already doing a short walk everyday is very good for you!

Your answers seem to indicate that you already do quite some exercise and active movement, still we advice you to increase this a little bit. It is healthy to exercise for at least 30 minutes at least five days a week. Try to find out what you like to do. Because if you like it, you can last longer. You move quite a it already, but more exercise is better!
How good that you exercise so much! You probably already notice that you feel good by exercising. If you keep doing this well, you have less chance of cardiovascular disease and diabetes (diabetes).

goal.name: AdviceFat
goal.description: Lifestyle Advice: Saturated and Trans Fat
goal.answer: You eat too much fat. Try to change this! Products with saturated and trans fat are very unhealthy. Saturated fat is commonly found in products as 48+ cheese, sausages, buttercream and chocalate, while trans fat is found in cookies, cake, chips and products from the fryer. Saturated fat and trans fat raise cholesterol. This increases the risk of obesity and arteriosclerosis and therefore more risk of cardiovascular disease, diabetes and problems with the kidneys. Unsaturated fat is healthier than saturated fat. It is important that you eat enough unsaturated fat. This can lower cholesterol. This reduces the risk of cardiovascular disease. Unsaturated fat is usually liquid. Unsaturated fat is, for example, in vegetable oils such as sunflower and olive oil.
You do not eat too much fat. That is very healthy!

goal.name: AdviceSugar
goal.answer: You eat too much sugar per day. The advice of the WHO is too eat less than 50 grams of added sugar per day. Sugars are basically energy. Excess energy is stored in your body as fat. Products with added sugars often contain so much energy that you get more energy than you need. This energy is therefore stored in our body as fat. Overweight and obesity (serious overweight) is therefore lurking when you get too much energy through sugars and overweight is strongly associated with higher risks of many types of diseases, so try to lower your suger intake!
You do not eat too much sugar. That is very healthy!

goal.name: AdviceFruit
goal.answer: For your health it is important to eat at least 2 pieces of fruit per day (200 gram). Fruit provides few calories and many nutrients. Fruit is good for your health and is associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular disease. In addition, eating fruit is associated with a lower risk of type 2 diabetes, colon cancer and lung cancer.
You eat at least two pieces of fruit every day. That is very healthy! If you eat a lot of fruit, you have less chance of health problems such as cardiovascular disease.

goal.name: AdviceVegetables
goal.answer: You don't eat enough vegetables. The advice is to eat at least 250 grams of vegetables per day. Vegetables are listed in the Wheel of Five. Vegetables provide few calories and many nutrients. Vegetables have many health benefits and are associated with a lower risk of chronic disease.

You eat at least 200 grams of vegetables every day. That is very healthy! If you eat a lot of vegetables, you have less chance of health problems such as cardiovascular disease, high blood pressure and diabetes. Vegetables contain many vitamins and minerals. These help you stay healthy. It is also important to eat a different type of vegetable every day. Through variation, your body receives different types of vitamins and minerals. That is even healthier. Continue with this!

goal.name: AdviceFish
goal.answer: You don't eat enough (oily) fish. Try to change this! Fish contains omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA). That is good for your heart and your cholesterol. Omega-3 fatty acids are mainly found in oily fish such as herring, mackerel, salmon, sardines and halibut.

goal.name: AdviceBreakfast
goal.answer: It is important to eat breakfast every day, eating breakfast every day gives you energy and allows you to concentrate better. If you do not eat breakfast every day, you are more likely to get diabetes. If you do have breakfast every day, your body will get energy at different times of the day. Moreover, you eat less (unhealthy) snacks when you have breakfast.

You have breakfast every day. That is very healthy! Eating breakfast every day gives you energy and allows you to concentrate better. If you do not eat breakfast every day, you are more likely to get diabetes. If you have breakfast every day, your body will get energy at different times of the day. Moreover, you eat less (unhealthy) snacks when you have breakfast.

goal.name: AdviceNuts
goal.answer: It is healthy to eat about 15 grams of nuts every day. That's about a hand. People who occasionally eat nuts are less likely to develop cardiovascular disease and have healthier cholesterol. It is important that they are unsalted nuts.

goal.name: AdviceTea
goal.answer: It is healthy to drink 3 or 4 cups of green or black tea every day. This can lower your blood pressure and reduce your risk of stroke.

goal.name: AdviceSmoking
goal.answer: People who smoke have more chanche of forming chronic diseases, like diabetes and usually have a shorter life expectancy. We advice you to consider lowering Smoking can cause all types of disaeases and is heavility related to the risk of forming diabates. We advice you to try and stop smoking. This website contians a lot of useful tips to help you quit: www.ikstopnu.nl

People who smoke have more chanches of forming chronic diseases, like diabetes and usually have a shorter life expectancy. It is therefore great that you quit smoking and we advice you to keep this up! After 1 year your chance of forming hart- and vascular diseases lowers by 50%, together with many other benefits.

goal.name: AdviceAlcohol
goal.answer: From your answers it seems that you drink a lot of alcohol, far above the adviced norm. We advivce you to lower this intake, concrete tips can be found on this website: https://minderdrinken.nl People who drink a lot of alcohol are more likely to have health problems. The more alcohol you drink, the more likely you are to have these health problems. Examples of these health problems are cardiovascular disease, cancer and damage to the brain and nerves. Drinking more than five glasses of alcohol every day can damage your coronary arteries. If you drink more than two glasses of alcohol a day, you are more likely to have a stroke. Drinking a lot of alcohol in a short period of time increases the risk of cardiovascular disease, kidney problems and damage to the brain.
It is better for your health if you do not drink more alcohol than one glass of alcohol per day. Then you adhere to the Moderate Alcohol Use Norm. We call this moderate drinking.

goal.name: AdviceStress
goal.answer: From your answers it seems that you experience problems from stress. Stress is a natural response of the body and mind to tensions. Stress can be both positive and negative. Stress is negative when you suffer from it. If you have a lot of stress for a long time, you can suffer from it both mentally and physically. Examples of physical complaints are headaches, muscle pain, sleeping problems and a greater risk of cardiovascular disease. Examples of mental complaints are depression, anxiety and burnout. We recommend that you discuss your concerns with someone you trust. That often relieves you and gives you support. This gives you a better overview, which gives you stress. Do you find talking difficult? It also helps to write down problems and how you feel. You can also seek professional help from an institution or organization.

Your answers show that you experience some problems that may be related to an imbalance between what you can handle and what you have to do in your daily life. If you have many obligations, problems and appointments for a longer period of time, this can cause a lot of tension (stress). If you also suffer from a reduced vitality, you can get overwhelmed. If you are overworked, you suffer from stress complaints and you function less well. It is important to think about this and talk to friends, family and experts about your situation.

rule.description: Lifestyle advice: exercise can be better
Lifestyle advice: too much sugar and sweets
Lifestyle advice: just too much alcohol

Type 1 ketoacidose: When someone suffers from the type 1 symmtoms in the past weeks and has passed out, we move directly to a ketoacidose advice, as you cannot waste time with this. We skip the lifestyle questions
Type 1 High Risk: If we find someone with a high risk of diabetes type 1, we skip the lifestyle questions, as adviced by our expert.
Type 1 Medium Risk: If we find someone with a medium risk of diabetes type 1, we skip the lifestyle questions, as adviced by our expert.

Type 1 Low Risk: If we find someone with a low risk of diabetes type 1 -> we state that the symptoms might be related to another disease, and we also check for diabetes type 2, after which we move to lifestyle questions.

Diagnose type 1: If someone suffers from diabetes related symptoms and these have started in the past few weeks, we check for diabetes type 1 risk first, if this turns out a dead end -> we also check for type 2.
Diagnose type 2: if someone suffers from symptoms related to diabetes, but these have not started in the past few weeks, the chance of diabetes 1 is very low, so we check for type 2.

Directly to lifestyle questions: If someone has not 1 symptom related to diabetes type 1 and 2, the risk is too low to pose unneccesarry questions about this, so we directly move to the lifestyle advice section.

question.description: Do you experience any of the following symptoms? You can select each one that you experience. dry mouth, frequently urinating, more than usually hungry, sudden weight losses/gains, blurry eye-sight?
Have these symptoms started suddenly in the last few weeks or shorter?

option.description: Yes, since a couple a weeks or less
No, I have experienced (at least some of) them longer than a couple of weeks

question.description: Have you fainted or experienced the feeling of fainting suddenly in the last few days?
Does anyone in your direct family have diabetes type 1? with direct family we only mean brothers, sisters, father, mother or sun and daugher
How old are you?
Do you identify as male or female?

What is your abdominal girth? You can measure you abdominal girth on your bare belly with measuring tape, make sure that you measure between the lowest rib and the belly button, make sure the measuring tape is horizontal.

What is your abdominal girth? You can measure you abdominal girth on your bare belly with measuring tape, make sure that you measure between the lowest rib and the belly button, make sure the measuring tape is horizontal.
What is your BMI?
Do you often feel tired or drained?
Do or did you ever smoke regularly?
Does anyone in your direct family have diabetes type 2? with direct family we only mean brothers, sisters, father, mother or sun and daugher
Are you from a Surinamese, Hindustani, Turkish or Moroccan descent? Note: These races have a genetic pre-disposition for diabetes type 2
For which of the following diseases have you been treated by a doctor?
Have you ever had pregnancy diabetes?

How many minutes of moderate and heavy exercise do you do per week? When answering the questions, think about a typical week in the past month. With 'Moderate effort' you still have enough breath to be able to talk. For example: walking briskly, climbing stairs, cycling briskly, swimming, gardening or vacuuming. With 'Heavy exertion' you start to sweat. Your breath is much faster and you cannot keep talking. For example: intensive sports, running, fast cycling or heavy physical work such as digging in the garden.
How many times do you have breakfast per week? Only a cup of coffee or tea is not considered a breakfast.
How much portions of fruit do you eat per day? A portion of fruit is about 100 gram
Do you eat a handful of nuts every day? A handful of nuts is about 15 gram.
How many cups of tea do you drink per day?
How many servings/slices of cheese do you eat per day? 1 portion/slice = 20 grams (about the amount on 1 sandwich)
Which cheese do you eat then?

option.description: Low-fat cheese: 10+, 20+ or 30+ (such as Milner, fresh goat cheese, cottage cheese, mozzarella)
Light full-fat cheese: 40+ or 48+ (such as Gouda, Edam, hard goat cheese)
Full-fat cheese: 50+ or 60+ (such as Brie, Paturain)

question.description: How many times per week do you eat fish?
How many times per week do you eat fried food?
How many servings of (whole grain) breakfast cereals, (brown) rice, whole grain pasta or other fiber-rich foods do you eat in a day? Non whole grain bread and crackers do not count here.
How often do you snack with chips, sausage or sausage rolls, for example?
How often do you eat a large portion of sweets, such as pastry, cake or chocolate?
How many teaspoons of sugar do you take in a day? We mean sugar that you add extra to your food. An example is sugar in the tea.
How many servings of vegetables, beans and / or raw vegetables do you eat on average per day? 1 serving is about 50 grams
Do or did you ever smoke in the last year?

option.description: I quit in this past year

question.description: How often do or did you smoke?
Do you smoke a cigarette, shag, cigar, cigarillo and / or pipe 10 or more times a day?
Do you drink alcohol?
How much alcohol do you drink per week?
How often did you experience stress at home this past year?
How often did you experience stress at work this past year?
How often did you experience stress from other things this past year?
Do you feel financial pressure?
Do you feel like you have a lot of energy?
Do you feel excitment when starting the day in the morning?
Which education did you finish? With finish, we mean where did you get a diploma from

option.description: I did not finish any education

question.description: Do you have cystitis / shortness of breath, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, stress?
